title: Annuity sales rise by a third
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Aug 11, 2015, 10:16 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 14 mins Annuity sales rise by a third By Richard Evans | Telegraph – 6 minutes ago 
Savers return to contoversial income-paying insurance policies after the steep decline following pension reforms announced in early 2014 
Demand for annuities has risen by a third in recent months, research shows. 
By the end of June demand had increased by 32pc on April’s level, according to the latest edition of the At Retirement Report from Iress, which supplies software to financial advisers. 
However, the rise represents only a small recovery following steep declines in the demand for annuities following the Government’s sweeping pension reforms announced in the Budget last year, which effectively abolished the compulsion to buy an annuity with pension savings. 
• Pension freedoms: Savers withdraw £1.8bn in three months 
In April, sales of “single-life” annuities (those that cover the policyholder only) fell by 7pc compared with March to reach their second lowest level on record, the report found. Sales had been lower only in December 2014, when the downturn in demand was accentuated by seasonal factors. 
“While the story on a month-by-month basis shows a slight bounceback in demand, it remains far below the level seen before the pension changes were announced,” Iress said. “Despite the June improvement, annuity activity is still 36pc below the level of two years ago.” 
The main alternative to buying an annuity, “income drawdown”, is growing in popularity, the report said. Statistics from the Association of British Insurers show that the number of drawdown contracts in the first quarter was higher 72pc than a year ago. 
“With an increasing number of investment products hitting the market now all the changes are in play, drawdown will continue to become more commonplace,” it said. “Annuity sales won’t rebound to their historic peak, but the moderate climb in interest in June does highlight how they remain an important, and often appropriate, option for retirees. 
• Five scenarios where annuities are still the best bet 
Annuity rates have also recovered slightly. The average rate for a standard single-life annuity at age 65 reached a six-month high of 5.1pc in June, compared with 4.86pc in March.
